query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
1 Taciti, soli, sanza compagnia 2 n’andavam l’un dinanzi e l’altro dopo, 3 come frati minor vanno per via.
query.result:
**English:**
1 Silent, alone, without company, 2 we went, one in front and the other behind, 3 like friars minor going on their way.
**Old English:**
1 Þa weard ic stille, ana sundor, butan gefērum, 2 we eodon forð, ān beforan and ān æfter, 3 swā swā gebrōðru dōð on wege.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
10 E come l’un pensier de l’altro scoppia, 11 così nacque di quello un altro poi, 12 che la prima paura mi fé doppia.
query.result:
**English:**
10 And as one thought bursts from another, 11 so from that one another was born, 12 which doubled my first fear.
**Old English:**
10 And swa swa ðæs anes ðoht ðæs oðres ðohte breac, 11 swa ðær of ðam oðer ðoht wearð geboren, 12 ðe me ða ða forman fyrhto twyfealde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
13 Io pensava così: ‘Questi per noi 14 sono scherniti con danno e con beffa 15 sì fatta, ch’assai credo che lor nòi.
query.result:
**English:**
13 I thought thus: ‘These people are scorned by us 14 with harm and mockery 15 so great that I believe their name is stained.
**Old English:**
13 Ic ða ðohte ðus: ‘Þas ðe we ðus 14 mid teonan and mid teonwordum 15 swa swiðe hwonlice hynðon.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
16 Se l’ira sovra ’l mal voler s’aggueffa, 17 ei ne verranno dietro più crudeli 18 che ’l cane a quella lievre ch’elli acceffa’.
query.result:
**English:**
16 If anger seizes upon the evil will, 17 they will come after us more cruelly 18 than the dog after the hare that it catches.
**Old English:**
16 Gif ðone yfelan willan ða wraðu oferswið, 17 ða cumað ða wyrsan him æfter 18 ðonne ðone haran ðe se hund ofslihð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
19 Già mi sentia tutti arricciar li peli 20 de la paura e stava in dietro intento, 21 quand’ io dissi: «Maestro, se non celi
22 te e me tostamente, i’ ho pavento 23 d’i Malebranche. Noi li avem già dietro; 24 io li ’magino sì, che già li sento».
query.result:
**English:**
19 Already I felt all my hair stand on end 20 from fear and stood there, intent, 21 when I said: "Master, if you do not hide
22 yourself and me quickly, I fear 23 the Malebranche. We have them already behind us; 24 I imagine them so that I already hear them."
**Old English:**
19 Þa ic feorran gehyrde ðara deofla hleopor 20 and ðara synfullra sawla wop and heora yfela geomerung, 21 þa ic cwæð: "La leofran min, hwæt is ðeos stefn ðe ic gehyrde?"
22 He ða cwæð: "Þis is ðara earmra sawla ðe forleton God and his beboda 23 and ðurh ða synna ðe hi geworhton syndon hi nu on ðære helle witu."
24 Þa ic ða ðæt gehyrde, þa weop ic ða swiðe sare 25 and cwæð: "La leofran min, hwæt synd ða synna ðe ðas earman sawla ðus wituð?"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
25 E quei: «S’i’ fossi di piombato vetro, 26 l’imagine di fuor tua non trarrei 27 più tosto a me, che quella dentro ’mpetro.
query.result:
**English:**
25 And he: "If I were made of leaded glass, 26 I would not draw your outward image to me 27 any more quickly than I do that which is imprinted within me.
**Old English:**
25 And se cwæð: "Gif ic wære of leaded glæs, 26 ðinre utanlican ansyne ic ne mihte geteon 27 to me selfum ðy hraðor ðonne ðæt ðe binnan me is."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
28 Pur mo venieno i tuo’ pensier tra ’ miei, 29 con simile atto e con simile faccia, 30 sì che d’intrambi un sol consiglio fei.
query.result:
**English:**
28 Just now your thoughts came to mine, 29 with similar action and similar appearance, 30 so that from both I made a single decision.
**Old English:**
28 Þa comon ðine ðancas to minum, 29 mid gelicum dædum and mid gelicum hiwe, 30 swa ðæt ic of unc bæm anum geþoht geworhte.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
31 S’elli è che sì la destra costa giaccia, 32 che noi possiam ne l’altra bolgia scendere, 33 noi fuggirem l’imaginata caccia».
query.result:
**English:**
31 If he is such that his right hip is lame, 32 so that we can descend into the other pouch, 33 we will escape the imagined chase.
**Old English:**
31 Gif he is ðæt his swiðre hippe licge, 32 ðæt we on ða oðre bolgan moten, 33 we ðone wænedan hunt ðurhfleon.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
34 Già non compié di tal consiglio rendere, 35 ch’io li vidi venir con l’ali tese 36 non molto lungi, per volerne prendere.
query.result:
**English:**
34 He had not yet finished giving such counsel, 35 when I saw them coming with their wings spread 36 not far away, to seize me.
**Old English:**
34 He næfde nâ giet ðæs gerædes geendod, 35 ðæt ic ðâ geseah ðâ feðerhoman fleogan 36 nealles wyrmlicu, me togeanes fleogan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
37 Lo duca mio di sùbito mi prese, 38 come la madre ch’al romore è desta 39 e vede presso a sé le fiamme accese,
40 che prende il figlio e fugge e non s’arresta, 41 avendo più di lui che di sé cura, 42 tanto che solo una camiscia vesta;
43 e giù dal collo de la ripa dura 44 supin si diede a la pendente roccia, 45 che l’un de’ lati a l’altra bolgia tura.
query.result:
**English:**
37 My leader suddenly seized me, 38 like a mother who is awakened by a noise 39 and sees the flames burning near her,
40 who seizes her child and flees and does not stop, 41 caring more for him than for herself, 42 so that she has only a chemise on;
43 and down from the neck of the hard bank 44 he gave himself supine to the sloping rock, 45 which blocks one side of the next pouch.
**Old English:**
37 Min heretoga ða fromlice me nam, 38 swa swa ðæt modor ðe ðurh hreoh bið awreht, 39 and ða neah ðære byrnende lig byð,
40 ðe ðone sunu nimeð and ðone fleogan læteð, 41 ðe mare lufeð ðonne hire agen lif, 42 ðæt heo næbbe næfre buton anum scrud;
43 and of ðæs steapes hals eode 44 on ða healfe ðære ufeweardan clife, 45 ðe ðære oðre bolge tosluteð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
46 Non corse mai sì tosto acqua per doccia 47 a volger ruota di molin terragno, 48 quand’ ella più verso le pale approccia,
49 come ’l maestro mio per quel vivagno, 50 portandosene me sovra ’l suo petto, 51 come suo figlio, non come compagno.
query.result:
**English:**
46 Never did water run so swiftly through a millrace 47 to turn the wheel of a mill on the ground, 48 when it approaches the paddles the most,
49 as my master along that narrow path, 50 carrying me on his chest, 51 as his son, not as a companion.
**Old English:**
46 Nefre ne ran wæter swa hræd ðurh rinen 47 to cyrrenne mylen hweol on eorðan, 48 ðonne hit nehst bið ðæra лопата,
49 swa min lareow ðurh ðone nearwan stigol, 50 bær me on his bosme, 51 swa his agen bearn, and na swa his gespelia.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
52 A pena fuoro i piè suoi giunti al letto 53 del fondo giù, ch’e’ furon in sul colle 54 sovresso noi; ma non lì era sospetto:
55 ché l’alta provedenza che lor volle 56 porre ministri de la fossa quinta, 57 poder di partirs’ indi a tutti tolle.
query.result:
**English:**
52 Scarcely had his feet reached the bottom 53 of the pit, when they were on the hill 54 above us; but there was no fear of them:
55 for the high providence that willed them 56 to be ministers of the fifth chasm, 57 takes away from all the power to depart from there.
**Old English:**
52 Swa hwæðre ne wæs ðær nan wen geleafa, 53 ðæt he ða mihte ðurh ða miclan mist 54 ðurh ða dimman wolcnu ðone weg findan, 55 ðe hine ðurh ða lyft lædan sceolde.
56 Ac ða ða he ða wolcnu ðurhwunode 57 and ða dimman ðe ðær binnan wæron, 58 ða geseah he ða ða sunnan scinan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
58 Là giù trovammo una gente dipinta 59 che giva intorno assai con lenti passi, 60 piangendo e nel sembiante stanca e vinta.
query.result:
**English:**
58 There we found a painted people 59 who went around very slowly, 60 weeping and in their appearance tired and defeated.
**Old English:**
58 Þær funde we folc swiðe manige 59 þe eodon be þæm wege swiðe slawlice, 60 wepende and on hyra ansyne swiðe gedrefede.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
61 Elli avean cappe con cappucci bassi 62 dinanzi a li occhi, fatte de la taglia 63 che in Clugnì per li monaci fassi.
query.result:
**English:**
61 They had cowls with low hoods 62 in front of their eyes, made of the same rough cloth 63 that is made for the monks in Cluny.
**Old English:**
61 Hihaefdonhæglæsmiðlæghædum 62 beforanheoraeagum,gemacodæsgegyrelan 63 ðe on Clugniaceðæm munecum byð gemacod.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
64 Di fuor dorate son, sì ch’elli abbaglia; 65 ma dentro tutte piombo, e gravi tanto, 66 che Federigo le mettea di paglia.
query.result:
**English:**
64 Outside they are gilded, so that they dazzle; 65 but inside they are all lead, and so heavy, 66 that Frederick would have considered them straw.
**Old English:**
64 Utan sind hi beorhte, swa ðæt hi ablendath; 65 ac innan hi sind ealle lead, and swa hefige, 66 ðæt Freðeric hi wolde ðincan to sceade.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
73 Per ch’io al duca mio: «Fa che tu trovi 74 alcun ch’al fatto o al nome si conosca, 75 e li occhi, sì andando, intorno movi».
query.result:
**English:**
73 Wherefore I said to my guide: "Arrange that you find 74 someone who is known by deed or name, 75 and as we go, keep your eyes moving around."
**Old English:**
73 Forðæm ic cwæð to ðam lærend: "Do ðæt ðu finde 74 ænigne ðe ðurh ðæt weorc oððe ðone naman beo gecnawen, 75 and ða eagan, swa gangende, ymbutan bewege."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
76 E un che ’ntese la parola tosca, 77 di retro a noi gridò: «Tenete i piedi, 78 voi che correte sì per l’aura fosca!
79 Forse ch’avrai da me quel che tu chiedi».
query.result:
**English:**
76 And one who understood the Tuscan word, 77 cried out behind us: "Hold your feet, 78 you who run so through the dark air!
79 Perhaps you will have from me what you ask for."
**Old English:**
76 And an ðe ða toscanan spræc ongeat, 77 æfter us clypode: "Haldað eowre fet, 78 ge ðe swa ðurh ðone dimman lyft rynnað!
79 Gemyne ðæt ðu miht ðurh me habban ðæt ðu bidest."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
80 Onde ’l duca si volse e disse: «Aspetta, 81 e poi secondo il suo passo procedi».
82 Ristetti, e vidi due mostrar gran fretta 83 de l’animo, col viso, d’esser meco; 84 ma tardavali ’l carco e la via stretta.
query.result:
**English:**
80 Whereupon the leader turned and said: “Wait, 81 and then proceed at his pace.”
82 I stopped, and I saw two showing great haste 83 of spirit, with their faces, to be with me; 84 but the burden and the narrow road held them back.
**Old English:**
80 Þa se heretoga wende and cwæð: “Abid, 81 and siððan æfter his gange gæ.”
82 Ic ðær stod and geseah twegen micelne hrade 83 modes myne, on andwlitan, to beonne mid me; 84 ac heora byrðen and se nearwe weg heora gang heora oferwann.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
85 Quando fuor giunti, assai con l’occhio bieco 86 mi rimiraron sanza far parola; 87 poi si volsero in sé, e dicean seco:
88 «Costui par vivo a l’atto de la gola; 89 e s’e’ son morti, per qual privilegio 90 vanno scoperti de la grave stola?».
query.result:
**English:**
85 When they had come to us, they looked at me askance 86 for a long time without speaking a word; 87 then they turned to each other and said among themselves:
88 "This one seems to be alive from the way he moves; 89 but if they are dead, by what privilege 90 do they go uncovered by the heavy robe?"
**Old English:**
85 Þa hie to us comon, hie wloncon on me 86 lange hwile buton ænige spræce; 87 ða hie wendon on heom sylfum and sædon him betwux:
88 "Þes ðinceð us lyfigende be ðæs lichoman drohtunge; 89 ac gif hie syndon deade, ðurh hwylcne freodom 90 gað hie nacode buton hefigan hrægle?"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
91 Poi disser me: «O Tosco, ch’al collegio 92 de l’ipocriti tristi se’ venuto, 93 dir chi tu se’ non avere in dispregio».
query.result:
**English:**
91 Then they said to me: "O Tuscan, who have come to the college 92 of the sad hypocrites, 93 do not disdain to tell who you are."
**Old English:**
91 Þa cwædon hie to me: "Eala ðu Toscisca, ðe to ðam gemanan 92 ðara leasunga earmra eart cumen, 93 ne forwyrn ðe ðæt ðu secge hwa ðu sy."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
94 E io a loro: «I’ fui nato e cresciuto 95 sovra ’l bel fiume d’Arno a la gran villa, 96 e son col corpo ch’i’ ho sempre avuto.
query.result:
**English:**
94 And I to them: "I was born and raised 95 above the fair river of Arno in the great city, 96 and I am with the body that I have always had.
**Old English:**
94 And ic him ða: "Ic wæs geboren and gefed 95 ofer ðam fægran flöde Arnes on ðære mæran byrig, 96 and ic eom mid ðam lichaman þe ic hæfde symle.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
97 Ma voi chi siete, a cui tanto distilla 98 quant’ i’ veggio dolor giù per le guance? 99 e che pena è in voi che sì sfavilla?».
query.result:
**English:**
97 But you, who are you, from whose eyes such pain 98 streams down your cheeks as I behold? 99 And what torment is in you that so shines forth?
**Old English:**
97 Ac ðu, hwa eart ðu, ðe ðus sare wepest 98 swa ic ðe on ðinum wlite geseo? 99 And hwæt is ðeos sarines ðe ðus scineð on ðe?

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
100 E l’un rispuose a me: «Le cappe rance 101 son di piombo sì grosse, che li pesi 102 fan così cigolar le lor bilance.
query.result:
**English:**
100 And one of them answered me: "The leaden cloaks 101 are so heavy that their weights 102 make their scales creak."
**Old English:**
100 And ða andswarode me sum: "Þa hreofe hleða 101 syndon of leade swa hefige, ðæt ða gewihta 102 doð swa gnyrran heora bilanca."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
103 Frati godenti fummo, e bolognesi; 104 io Catalano e questi Loderingo 105 nomati, e da tua terra insieme presi
106 come suole esser tolto un uom solingo, 107 per conservar sua pace; e fummo tali, 108 ch’ancor si pare intorno dal Gardingo».
query.result:
**English:**
103 We were joyful friars, and Bolognese; 104 I am Catalano and this one Loderingo 105 by name, and from your land we were taken together,
106 as a solitary man is often taken 107 to preserve his peace; and such were we, 108 that it is still evident around the Gardingo."
**Old English:**
103 We wæron blide gebróðra, and Bolognian; 104 ic Catalano and ðes Loderingo 105 genemnode, and of ðínum earde ætgædere genumene,
106 swá swá man gewuna is ánne man geniman, 107 forðæmðe he his sibbe gehealde; and we wæron swylce, 108 ðæt hit is gyt gesýne ymb ðone Gardingo."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
109 Io cominciai: «O frati, i vostri mali . . . »; 110 ma più non dissi, ch’a l’occhio mi corse 111 un, crucifisso in terra con tre pali.
query.result:
**English:**
109 I began: "O brothers, your evil ways . . . "; 110 but I said no more, for my eye caught sight of 111 one crucified on the ground with three stakes.
**Old English:**
109 Ic ongan ða: "Eala gebroðra, eowre yfel . . . "; 110 ac ða ne sæde ic na mare, forðæm ðe minum eagum wearð gesyne 111 an on rode fæst on eorðan mid ðrim stacum.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
112 Quando mi vide, tutto si distorse, 113 soffiando ne la barba con sospiri; 114 e ’l frate Catalan, ch’a ciò s’accorse,
115 mi disse: «Quel confitto che tu miri, 116 consigliò i Farisei che convenia 117 porre un uom per lo popolo a’ martìri.
query.result:
**English:**
112 When he saw me, he twisted all over, 113 blowing on his beard with sighs; 114 and Brother Catalano, who noticed this,
115 said to me: “That condemned man you see there, 116 advised the Pharisees that it was fitting 117 to put one man to death for the people.
**Old English:**
112 Þa he mec geseah, eal he hine bewende, 113 blæwende on his beard mid sorhfullum sighum; 114 and broðor Catalanus, se ðe ðæs georne nam,
115 sæde me: “Þes awyrgda ðe ðu her geseoð, 116 rædde ðam Fariseum ðæt riht wære 117 an man for ðam folce to deade syllan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
118 Attraversato è, nudo, ne la via, 119 come tu vedi, ed è mestier ch’el senta 120 qualunque passa, come pesa, pria.
query.result:
**English:**
118 He has crossed it, naked, on the road, 119 as you see, and it is necessary that he feel 120 whoever passes, how much he weighs, first.
**Old English:**
118 He hæfð oferfaren nacod ðone weg, 119 swa ðu gesihst, and hit is neod ðæt he gefola 120 hwa swa ðær ofer gæð, hu micle he wege, ær.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
121 E a tal modo il socero si stenta 122 in questa fossa, e li altri dal concilio 123 che fu per li Giudei mala sementa».
query.result:
**English:**
121 And in such manner the father-in-law is tormented 122 in this ditch, and the others of the council 123 that was an evil seed for the Jews.
**Old English:**
121 And on ðære wisan ðæs sweores fæder 122 on ðam dic wunað, and ða oðre ðæs gemotes 123 ðe wæs ðam Iudeum yfel sæd.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
124 Allor vid’ io maravigliar Virgilio 125 sovra colui ch’era disteso in croce 126 tanto vilmente ne l’etterno essilio.
query.result:
**English:**
124 Then I saw Virgil marvel 125 over the one who was stretched out on the cross, 126 so vilely in eternal exile.
**Old English:**
124 Þa geseah ic ðær Virgilium wundrian 125 ofer ðæm ðe wæs on rode ahafen, 126 swa leahtlice on ðam ecan exsilie.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
127 Poscia drizzò al frate cotal voce: 128 «Non vi dispiaccia, se vi lece, dirci 129 s’a la man destra giace alcuna foce
130 onde noi amendue possiamo uscirci, 131 sanza costrigner de li angeli neri 132 che vegnan d’esto fondo a dipartirci».
query.result:
**English:**
127 Then he addressed the friar in this voice: 128 "Do not be displeased, if it is permitted to you to tell us, 129 if there is any outlet on the right hand side
130 through which we both can get out of here, 131 without having to compel the black angels 132 to come up from this depth to separate us".
**Old English:**
127 Þa he ðone freond mid ðyssum wordum wec: 128 "Ne beo ðe lað, gif ðu meaht secgan, 129 gif ænig utgang is on ðære swiðran healfe
130 ðurh ðone we magon begen gesunde 131 butan ðære sweartran engla hæfte 132 ðe us of ðissum grundum lædað".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
133 Rispuose adunque: «Più che tu non speri 134 s’appressa un sasso che da la gran cerchia 135 si move e varca tutt’ i vallon feri,
136 salvo che ’n questo è rotto e nol coperchia; 137 montar potrete su per la ruina, 138 che giace in costa e nel fondo soperchia».
query.result:
**English:**
133 He replied: "More quickly than you hope, 134 a rock is approaching that moves from the great circle 135 and crosses all the wild valleys,
136 except that it is broken in this one and does not cover it; 137 you will be able to climb up the ruin, 138 which lies on the slope and juts out at the bottom."
**Old English:**
133 He ða andswarode: "Raðor ðonne ðu wene, 134 nealæcð ðe stan of ðære miclan mearce 135 ðe ðurh ða wudu wyrðð, and ða wælfelda,
136 buton ðisum anum ðe he ðurh ne mæg; 137 ðu miht ðone stigol stigan on ðære steape, 138 ðe ðær on ðam sidan ligeð and ðone sæ oferhlifað."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
139 Lo duca stette un poco a testa china; 140 poi disse: «Mal contava la bisogna 141 colui che i peccator di qua uncina».
query.result:
**English:**
139 The leader stood for a while with bowed head; 140 then he said: "He who ensnares the sinners here 141 told the story badly."
**Old English:**
139 Se heretoga stod ða hwile heafde gebogen; 140 ða cwæð he: "Yfele sægde ða gesceaft 141 se ðe ða synfullan her onwrigen hæfð."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
142 E ’l frate: «Io udi’ già dire a Bologna 143 del diavol vizi assai, tra ’ quali udi’ 144 ch’elli è bugiardo, e padre di menzogna».
query.result:
**English:**
142 And the friar: "I once heard it said in Bologna 143 of many vices of the devil, among which I heard 144 that he is a liar, and the father of lies."
**Old English:**
142 And se friar: "Ic udi' geara secgan on Bononia 143 ðæs deofles unþeawas fela, ðara ic udi' 144 ðæt he is leas and lyge fæder."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
145 Appresso il duca a gran passi sen gì, 146 turbato un poco d’ira nel sembiante; 147 ond’ io da li ’ncarcati mi parti’
148 dietro a le poste de le care piante.
query.result:
**English:**
145 Behind the leader I went with great strides, 146 somewhat troubled with anger in his countenance; 147 wherefrom I departed from those burdened ones,
148 following the tracks of his dear feet.
**Old English:**
145 Æfter ðæm heretogan ic mid miclum stæpum eode, 146 sumhwæt getremed on ðæm ansyne mid yrre; 147 ðanon ic fram ðæm byrðenum me gewende,
148 æfter ðæm sporum ðæra dyreða fota.
